text: 1. VÂ G A S RAVASA 1 , desirous (of heavenly rewards), surrendered (at a sacrifice) all that he possessed. He had a son of the name of Na k iketas.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 2. When the (promised) presents were being given (to the priests), faith entered into the heart of Na k iketas, who was still a boy, and he thought:

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 3. 'Unblessed 2 , surely, are the worlds to which a man goes by giving (as his promised present at a sacrifice) cows which have drunk water, eaten hay, given their milk 3 , and are barren.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 4. He (knowing that his father had promised to give up all that he possessed, and therefore his son also) said to his father: 'Dear father, to whom wilt thou give me?'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: He said it a second and a third time. Then the father replied (angrily):

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 'I shall give thee 1 unto Death.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: (The father, having once said so, though in haste, had to be true to his word and to sacrifice his son.)

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 5. The son said: 'I go as the first, at the head of many (who have still to die); I go in the midst of many (who are now dying). What will be the work of Yama (the ruler of the departed) which to-day he has to do unto me 2 ?

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 6. 'Look back how it was with those who came before, look forward how it will be with those who come hereafter. A mortal ripens like corn, like corn he springs up again 1 .'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: (Na k iketas enters into the abode of Yama Vaivasvata, and there is no one to receive him. Thereupon one of the attendants of Yama is supposed to say:)

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 7. 'Fire enters into the houses, when a Brâhma n a enters as a guest 2 . That fire is quenched by this peace-offering;--bring water, O Vaivasvata 3 !

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 8. 'A Brâhma n a that dwells in the house of a foolish man without receiving food to eat, destroys his hopes and expectations, his possessions, his righteousness, his sacred and his good deeds, and all his sons and cattle 4 .'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: (Yama, returning to his house after an absence of three nights, during which time Na k iketas had received no hospitality from him, says:)

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 9. 'O Brâhma n a, as thou, a venerable guest, hast dwelt in my house three nights without eating,

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: therefore choose now three boons. Hail to thee! and welfare to me!'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 10. Na k iketas said: 'O Death, as the first of the three boons I choose that Gautama, my father, be pacified, kind, and free from anger towards me; and that he may know me and greet me, when I shall have been dismissed by thee.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 11. Yama said: 'Through my favour Auddâlaki Âru n i, thy father, will know thee, and be again towards thee as he was before. He shall sleep peacefully through the night, and free from anger, after having seen thee freed from the mouth of death.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 12. Na k iketas said: 'In the heaven-world there is no fear; thou art not there, O Death, and no one is afraid on account of old age. Leaving behind both hunger and thirst, and out of the reach of sorrow, all rejoice in the world of heaven.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 13. 'Thou knowest, O Death, the fire-sacrifice which leads us to heaven; tell it to me, for I am full of faith. Those who live in the heaven-world reach immortality,--this I ask as my second boon.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 14. Yama said: 'I tell it thee, learn it from me, and when thou understandest that fire-sacrifice which leads to heaven, know, O Na k iketas, that it is the attainment of the endless worlds, and their firm support, hidden in darkness 1 .'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 15. Yama then told him that fire-sacrifice, the beginning of all the worlds 2 , and what bricks are

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: required for the altar, and how many, and how they are to be placed. And Na k iketas repeated all as it had been told to him. Then M ri tyu, being pleased with him, said again:

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 16. The generous 1 , being satisfied, said to him:

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: I give thee now another boon; that fire-sacrifice shall be named after thee, take also this many-coloured chain 2 .'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 17. 'He who has three times performed this Nâ k iketa rite, and has been united with the three (father, mother, and teacher), and has performed the three duties (study, sacrifice, almsgiving) overcomes birth and death. When he has learnt and understood this fire, which knows (or makes us know) all that is born of Brahman 3 , which is venerable and divine, then he obtains everlasting peace.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 18. 'He who knows the three Nâ k iketa fires, and knowing the three, piles up the Nâ k iketa sacrifice, he, having first thrown off the chains of death, rejoices in the world of heaven, beyond the reach of grief.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 19. 'This, O Na k iketas, is thy fire which leads to heaven, and which thou hast chosen as thy second boon. That fire all men will proclaim 4 . Choose now, O Na k iketas, thy third boon.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 20. Na k iketas said: 'There is that doubt, when a man is dead,--some saying, he is; others, he is not. This I should like to know, taught by thee; this is the third of my boons.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 21. Death said: 'On this point even the gods

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: have doubted formerly; it is not easy to understand. That subject is subtle. Choose another boon, O Na k iketas, do not press me, and let me off that boon.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 22. Na k iketas said: 'On this point even the gods have doubted indeed, and thou, Death, hast declared it to be not easy to understand, and another teacher like thee is not to be found:--surely no other boon is like unto this.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 23. Death said: 'Choose sons and grandsons who shall live a hundred years, herds of cattle, elephants, gold, and horses. Choose the wide abode of the earth, and live thyself as many harvests as thou desirest.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 24. 'If you can think of any boon equal to that, choose wealth, and long life. Be (king), Na k iketas, on the wide earth 1 . I make thee the enjoyer of all desires.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 25. 'Whatever desires are difficult to attain among mortals, ask for them according to thy wish;--these fair maidens with their chariots and musical instruments,--such are indeed not to be obtained by men,--be waited on by them whom I give to thee, but do not ask me about dying.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 26. Na k iketas said: 'These things last till tomorrow, O Death, for they wear out this vigour of all the senses. Even the whole of life is short. Keep thou thy horses, keep dance and song for thyself.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 27. 'No man can be made happy by wealth. Shall we possess wealth, when we see thee? Shall we live,

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: as long as thou rulest? Only that boon (which I have chosen) is to be chosen by me.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 28. 'What mortal, slowly decaying here below, and knowing, after having approached them, the freedom from decay enjoyed by the immortals, would delight in a long life, after he has pondered on the pleasures which arise from beauty and love 1 ?'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 29. 'No, that on which there is this doubt, O Death, tell us what there is in that great Hereafter. Na k iketas does not choose another boon but that which enters into the hidden world.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 1:1 Vâ g a s ravasa is called Âru n i Auddâlaki Gautama, the father of Na k iketas. The father of S vetaketu, another enlightened pupil (see Kh ând. Up. VI, 1, 1), is also called Âru n i (Uddâlaka, comm. Kaush. Up. I, x) Gautama. S vetaketu himself is called Âru n eya, i.e. the son of Âru n i, the grandson of Âru n a, and likewise Auddâlaki. Auddâlaki is a son of Uddâlaka, but S aṅkara (Kâ th . Up. I, 11) takes Auddâlaki as possibly the same as Uddâlaka. See B ri h. Âr. Up. III, 6, 1.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 1:2 As to @änanda@, unblessed, see B ri h. Âr. Up. IV, 4, 11; Vâ g as. Sa m h. Up. 3 (Sacred Books of the East, vol. i, p. 310.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 1:3 Ânandagiri explains that the cows meant here are cows no longer able to drink, to eat, to give milk, and to calve.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 2:1 Dadâmi, I give, with the meaning of the future. Some MSS. write dâsyâmi.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 2:2 I translate these verses freely, i.e. independently of the commentator, not that I ever despise the traditional interpretation which the commentators have preserved to us, but because I think that, after having examined it, we have a right to judge for ourselves. S aṅkara says that the son, having been addressed by his father full of anger, was sad, and said to himself: 'Among many pupils I am the first, among many middling pupils I am the middlemost, but nowhere am I the last. Yet though I am such a good pupil, my father has said that he will consign me unto death. What duty has he to fulfil toward Yama which he means to fulfil to-day by giving me to him? There may be no duty, he may only have spoken in haste. Yet a father's word must not be broken.' Having considered this, the son comforted his father, and exhorted him to behave like his forefathers, and to keep his word. I do not think this view of S aṅkara's could have been the view of the old poet. He might have made the son say that he was the best or one of the best of his father's pupils, but hardly that he was also one of his middling pupils, thus implying that he never was among the worst. That would be out of keeping with the character of Na k iketas, as drawn by the poet himself. Na k iketas is full of faith and wishes to die, he would be the last to think of excuses why he should not die. The second half of the verse may be more doubtful. It may mean what S aṅkara thinks it means, only that we should get thus again an implied complaint of Na k iketas against his father, and this is not in keeping with his character. The mind of Na k iketas is bent on what is to come, on what he will see after death, and on what Yama will do unto him. 'What has Yama to do,' he asks, 'what can he do, what is it that he will to-day do unto p. 3 me?' This seems to me consistent with the tenor of the ancient story, while S aṅkara's interpretations and interpolations savour too much of the middle ages of India.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 3:1 Sasyâ, corn rather than grass; εἴα, ἤιον Benfey; Welsh haidd, according to Rhys; different from s ash-pa, ces-pes, Benfey.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 3:2 Cf. Vasish th a XI, 13; Sacred Books of the East, vol. xiv, p. 51.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 3:3 Vaivasvata, a name of Yama, the ruler of the departed. Water is the first gift to be offered to a stranger who claims hospitality.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 3:4 Here again some words are translated differently from S aṅkara. He explains â s â as asking for a wished-for object, pratikshâ as looking forward with a view to obtaining an unknown object. Saṅgata he takes as reward for intercourse with good people; sûn ri tâ, as usual, as good and kind speech; ish t a as rewards for sacrifices; pûrta as rewards for public benefits.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 4:1 The commentator translates: 'I tell it thee, attend to me who knows the heavenly fire.' Here the nom. sing. of the participle would be very irregular, as we can hardly refer it to bravîmi. Then, 'Know this fire as a means of obtaining the heavenly world, know that fire as the rest or support of the world, when it assumes the form of Virâ g , and as hidden in the heart of men.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 4:2 S aṅkara: the first embodied, in the shape of Virâ g .

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 5:1 Verses 16-18 seem a later addition.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 5:2 This arises probably from a misunderstanding of verse 11, 3.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 5:3 G âtavedas.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 5:4 Tavaiva is a later addition, caused by the interpolation of verses 15-18.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 6:1 Mahâbhûmau, on the great earth, has been explained also by mahâ bhûmau, be great on the earth. It is doubtful, however, whether mahi for mahin could be admitted in the Upanishads, and whether it would not be easier to write mahân bhûmau.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 7:1 A very obscure verse. S aṅkara gives a various reading kva tadâstha h for kvadha h stha h , in the sense of I given to these pleasures,' which looks like an emendation. I have changed a g îryatâm into a g âryatâm, and take it for an acc. sing., instead of a gen. plur., which could hardly be governed by upetya.
